goal.ch:
“1. Knowledge of Human Resource Development Theory and Practice: Students will understand the major components of HRD theory by using lecture and seminar. Students will:
(1) Demonstrate comprehension of complex theoretical constructs in the major HRD disciplines.
(2) Be familiar with HRD literature. 
(3) Develop awareness of emerging trends in HRD disciplines and practices.
2. Original Contribution：Students will be able to create knowledge through original research in HRD fields. Students will: 
(1) Use qualitative and quantitative methods to develop a workable research proposal.“

outline.en:
“High potential employees
 Silzer, R. ＆ Church, A.H. (2009). The pearls and perils of identifying potential. Industrial and Organizational Psychology, 2: 377-412.
 Dries, N., ＆ Pepermans, R. (2012). How to identify leadership potential: Development and testing of a consensus model, Human Resource Management, 51(3): 361-385.
 Dries, N., ＆ Pepermans, R. (2007). Using emotional intelligence to identify high potential: a metacompetency perspective. Leadership ＆ Organhizational Development Journal, 28(8), 749-770.
Career success
 Dries, N. (2011). The meaning of career success. Career Development International, 16(4), 364-384.
 Seibert, S. E., Kraimer, M. L., ＆ Liben, R. C. (2001).  A social capital theory of career success. Academy of Management Journal, 44(2), 219-237.
 De Pater E. Irene, Vianen Van, E. M. Annelies, Myriam N. Bechtoldt, and Ute-Christine Klehe. (2009). Employees’ Challenging Job Experiences and Supervisors’ Evaluations of Promotability. Personnel Psychology, 62, 297-325.
 Harris, K. J., Kacmar, K. M., ＆ Carlson, D. S. (2006). An Examination of Temporal Variables and Relationship Quality on Promotability Ratings. Group ＆ Organization Management, 677-699.
 Ng, T. W .H., Eby, L.T., Sorensen, K.L., ＆ Feldman, D.C. (2005). Predictors of objective and subjective career success: A meta-analysis. Personnel Psychology, 58: 367-408.
 Eby, L. T., Butts, M. M., ＆ Lockwood, A. L. (2003). Predictors of success in the era of the boundaryless career. Journal of Organizational Behavior, 24: 689-709.
 Briscoe, J. P., Hall, D. T., Frautschy DeMuthR. L., (2006). Protean and boundaryless careers: A empirical exploration, 69, 30-47.
Succession planning
 Shen, W., ＆ Cannella, A. A. (2003). Will succession planning increase shareholder wealth? Evidence from investor reactions to relay CEO successions. Strategic Management Journal, 24, 191-198.
 Lin, A., ＆ Li, D. (2004). The performance consequences of top management successions: The roles organizational and environmental context. Group and Organizational Management, 29(1), 32-66.
Networking
 Chua, R. Y. J, Morris, M. W., ＆ Ingram, P. (2009). Guanxi vs. networking: Distinctive configurations of affect- and cognitive-based trust in the networks of Chinese and American. Journal of International Business Studies, 40, 490-508.
 Chua, R. Y. J, Ingram, P., ＆ Morris, M. W. (2008). From the head and the heart: Locating cognition- and affect-based trust in managers’ professional networks. Academy of Management Journal, 51(3), 436-452.
Career development
 Zaleska, K. J., ＆ de Menezes, L. M. (2007). Human resource development practices and their association with employee attitudes: Between new and traditional careers, Human Relations, 60(7), 987-1018.
 Bambacas, M., ＆ Bordia, P. (2009). Predicting different commitment components: The relative effects of how career development HRM practices are perceived. Journal of Management ＆ Organization, 15, 224-220.
Research Motivation
 Whetten, D. A. (1989). What constitutes a theoretical contribution? Academy of Management Review, 14(4): 490-495.“
